p: ZIKV is a member of the genus Flavivirus and urban transmission is predominantly driven by Aedes aegypti 2 , 4. Locally acquired ZIKV infections in Australia have not been reported, however, endemic populations of Ae. aegypti constantly warrants rigorous disease surveillance and mosquito control strategies 4. Indeed, since 2012, 68 cases of imported ZIKV infection have been reported in Australia up until August 2016 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/ohp-zika-notifications.htm). Concern also exists because recent evidence has implicated ZIKV infection in severe neurological disorders such as microcephaly in newborns and Guillain-Barr√© syndrome 2.
